title: Move % Bonus HP from Cinderhulk to Warmogs
body:
Just wondering what everyone things about moving the bonus health from the cinderhulk items {{item:3709}} {{item:3717}} {{item:3721}} {{item:3725}} to the original "I want a ton of health" item {{item:3083}}.


Personally, I don't feel that the bonus scaling health makes sense to be tied into a jungle-only item. AP champs have {{item:3089}} to grant them % bonus, {{item:3031}} does roughly the same thing for AD, yet only the current similar tank item requires you to have a certain summoner spell as a prerequisite.

Besides, I thought the main idea behind giving junglers an item similar to {{item:3068}}  was to improve clear times, not improve their overall scaling. If Riot feels that tanks need such an item to improve late game scaling, it should be added separately from the jungle in order to benefit the entire tank class.

I think Warmog's is a good fit for this effect. I rarely seen it built any more, and moving the health scaling here would, in my opinion, better align it to the "ton of health" theme. 

TL;DR: look at the title....

So, what does everyone think?

___________________________________


Edit: 

So, of course we would have to tweak a lot of numbers to rebalance the items. Many stats would need to be shifted around. We would have to look at Warmogs current passive, and see if it could coexist with the added % bonus health. This part of the argument has to do with balancing this idea.

However, I'm what I'm wanting to do is to give these items back a core identity. Cinderhulk for jungle clear and sustained damage in fight, Warmog's for mega-tanks. Currently, Cinderhulk's identity is being OP for everything a tank could possibly want. On the other hand, Warmog's identity has been somewhat lost in my opinion. Riot can make anything not OP by nerfing numbers, but I'm hoping to discuss whether these changes will give them a better role in the game.

Thank you all for your input!

replies.body: I think they should both have it, but as unique passives so they cant stack with eachother.

And not the massive out-of-combat health regen? Now EVERYONE can be {{champion:86}}...

It doesn't matter if they're both unique passives, since they are two unique items they would still stack. For example, both {{item:3142}} and {{item:3071}} build out of a {{item:3134}} and have a unique armor penetration passive, yet if you own all three you still get all the armor penetration.



It has to be a unique named passive like Immolate in order for it to work that way, but if you did that it would just be restricting junglers even more, because {{item:3717}} would then be mutually exclusive and prevent people from buying not only {{item:3068}} but also {{item:3083}}. It's really not a smart idea IMO, if a jungler wants scaling health they could just buy {{item:3083}}.
Why am I being downvoted so heavily? Do people really want tank junglers to not be able to buy either {{item:3068}} or {{item:3083}}?

I think it started with the misunderstanding about unique passives, then you were at -1 already, and people end up more likely to downvote already negative comments. Because they didn't like the first part of your comment, they missed your really good point about limiting item paths.
But that happens because when you upgrade {{item:3134}} to either {{item:3071}} or {{item:3142}}  it looses the unique trait of CDR.
But all 3 of those have 10% cdr, so I don't get how it loses it, and it does stack lol

Brutalizer has UNIQUE Passive: 10% CDR and UNIQUE Passive: Armor Penetration because by itself it's a very eficient item and you could only stack Brutalizers without upgrading them for becoming a monster. My  guess is, since AD casters have a very little item pool (CDR items I mean), Riot decided that they could stack the CDR once you have completed one of them.
My bad. I was thinking of the armor penetration passive, not the CDR. I got them mixed up.

The jungle item has it because it was explicitly jungle tanks that were having problems.

Also, infinity edge is nothing like a rabadons or cinderhulk for AD champions, because if it were, AD assassins would be picking it up left and right. Mages get a ridiculously powerful multiplier like Rabadons because they specifically NEED that multiplier to be viable - if they couldn't get absurd amounts of AP in the 600-800 range, they would be useless. Similarly, jungle tanks NEED the ridiculously strong multiplier from cinderhulk to be viable - while lane tanks (Maokai, Cho'Gath, Hecarim) generally do not.

This is exactly right. 

Take %HP off Cinderhulk and Sejuani, Nautilus, Amumu, etc. are all dead champions again. It's the only thing that allows them to stand up to Vi/J4/Lee Sin, and without it being jungle exclusive top laners will fill the tank role while we go back to Warrior/BC/tank items bruisers in the jungle.

% HP really doesn't have that huge an impact at the very start of the game, which is where jungle tanks have always been weakest. An absolutely awful early game is what kept tank junglers out. What really lets them power through the early game is Cinderhulk's aura damage, which improves their clear speed. This is the primary reason tank junglers are now viable.

Obviously, if we remove the %HP, the flat HP on the item would have to be increased (or other stats added to it). This would technically make the item stronger in the early game than it is now. If you think % HP is needed to make jungle tanks relevant, when it only should affect late game when you have already built multiple health items, then I think that is a statement towards how tanks might be an underpowered role overall currently (unless they have the OP Cinderhulk). However, if they would still be able to build a different item with %HP after my suggested change, they will have lost very little of their current strength. Except their power will just not be entirely focused on one item.

Anyways, I think we all know Cinderhulk is going to get nerfed soon. Tanks are now crowding out other junglers with it (went from not viable to too viable). Cinderhulk will need to be weakened in some way, and I think it's scaling would be the best place to target.

Tanks are a weak role without Cinderhulk around. Jungle bruisers have access to Warrior enchantment, one of the most cost efficient items in League of Legends, which gives them incredible early game burst that allows them to shit on your lanes 10 times harder than any tank jungler can. The only thing tank junglers have against the bruisers is Cinderhulk's jungle-exclusive %HP, which ensures that once late game comes around, tanks who build Cinderhulk will be much bulkier than Warrior junglers. If Warrior junglers want to be as bulky as Cinderhulkers, they have to either build Cinderhulk instead of Warrior (forfeiting their massive early game burst advantage) or sell Warrior for Cinderhulk late game (too expensive to do until 6 item full build). 

Without Cinderhulk in its current state, bruisers can outburst tanks early game and then transition into a champion who does much more damage while only being slightly squishier. Same goes for if %HP is added to another item without being taken off Cinderhulk. The way Cinderhulk works forces bruisers to choose between damage-focused and tank-focused builds in a way they've never had to choose in League's history, and I'd prefer it stay that way unless we have a very, VERY good reason to let bruisers run the league again. 

TL;DR: Without Cinderhulk, bruisers burst you for 75% of your health while also being tanks, while tanks burst you for 40% and are only tanks. With cinderhulk, bruisers either burst you for 50% of your health and are also semi-tanks, or they burst you for 75% of your health while not being tanks, and tanks burst you for 40% of your health while being so bulky that they actually deserve the name "tank".

But isn't the whole idea of % bonus HP meant to benefit tanks more than bruisers? The way to maximize its efficiency is to buy a lot of HP heavy items. If bruisers are doing this, they sacrifice damage for it. If they build damage, other items would be more efficient than the % bonus HP. Thus, if balanced properly, the new Warmogs could not be abused by bruisers.

Cinderhulk's bonus HP doesn't stand on his own, though - rather, it is placed on an item that has another primary purpose: Cinderhulk gives tanks a way to clear the jungle more efficiently, something they were lacking before compared to Warrior-building bruisers.

If the %-bonus HP effect was placed on another item, this distinguishing effect Mi Ramfan is describing would vanish - bruiser junglers would just build Warrior into the %-bonus HP item into tank and again burst you for 75% of your health on top of being the team's main tanks.

We can somewhat see this already with the top lane Smites - Hecarim or Shyv with Skirmisher's Cinderhulk and one offensive item (Triforce/BotRK respectively) are fully-fledged tanks that still have the power to destroy squishies in mere seconds.

The idea behind %-bonus HP is indeed for it to benefit tanks more so than bruisers. However, it commonly gets mixed up how it is supposed to help tanks. Because, actually, you're not supposed to just build additional HP items to maximize your tanks efficiency. Rather, the bonus effect is there to allow you to build items that don't necessarily give you a ton of HP (like {{item:3110}} or {{item:3075}} ) and still get an appropriate amount of health for a tank.
Which makes me wonder why you want the % HP scaling removed from Cinderhulk.  If you replace it with flat health, then fighters will have even safer clears and provide more ganks.
Except top laners are filling the tank role... with YOUR supposedly tank jungler exclusive item.

Yes, and they're giving up a Summoner Spell to do it. 

There are two main points of Cinderhulk. Firstly, that it improves the early game clears of tank junglers without forcing them to build suboptimal damage items; secondly, and more importantly, it changes the definition of a tank from "someone who builds 3 bulk items after their Warrior/Triforce start" to "someone who has Cinderhulk/boots/4 tank items". 

Essentially, what Cinderhulk means is that if the Lee Sin/Vi/Jarvan/Wukong crowd want to be bruisers who do bruiser things, they can still do that by building Warrior, but they cannot be tanks because tanks are people who build Cinderhulk (thanks to the %HP). 

Cinderhulk is so successful at reviving the idea of "tanks" in S4/S5's burst focus metas that aggressive top laners like Hecarim and Shyvana are GIVING UP SUMMONER SPELLS to be tanks instead of bruisers. Giving up flash is a substantial loss in safety, especially for those two who are balls deep, in your face fighters throughout the game. Cinderhulk is so good that it's causing bruisers, the class which has always been the "have your cake and that of the assassins and tanks, and eat it too" of League of Legends, to choose not to be bruisers so that they can be tanks.

That's the beauty of this item. If it's good enough that even top laners have decided that they want to be tanks (the black sheep of League of Legends), then it's having a positive impact on League that Riot hasn't hit in all its years are tinkering. Bruisers are finally the class they were always meant to be: they can be a tank if you need a tank, or a DPS if you need a DPS, but never both at the same time, and that's a GOOD THING. 

We should be very, very careful about any change that risks throwing that away. Personally, we should be considering individual hits to Sejuani/Amumu to avoid hitting Cinderhulk.

I don't see many people doing this for other enchantments, such as Warrior, though Armor Penetration options are somewhat limited. Get Youmuu + BC + Warrior, that's 40 Armor shredded on top of your runes and BC passive, which would still be incredibly useful. However, the cost is a deterrent from that; Cinderhulk is strong enough to break that mold because:

A. its damage effect (Immolate) actually becomes stronger than its non-jungle counterpart.
B. It has realistic endgame item potential for a laner.

Yes, they have revived tanks with this item a lot. However, that's because of poor itemization outside of jungle items, and jungle items should not be covering that void. When laners will grab these items in sacrifice of a Summoner Spell slot, that means champions are willing to grab useless stats (namely the first 850g, save the Smite effect) to get this item. Imagine the overflowing power on a champion that actually *needs* the regeneration and monster damage effects, which is what we're *supposed* to buy the jungle items for. Of course we have a tank meta, you'd be stupid not to be a tank with Cinderhulk out there, and **that's** why top-laners grabbing it is actually a BAD THING.

It's true that tanks have poor itemization outside of Cinderhulk, but that truth hides a greater problem. Tank itemization has been extremely weak for years because of the incredible power of S1/S2's bruisers with the infamous "metagolem" build (Merc Treads/Frozen Mallet/Warmogs/Atmas/Triforce), which caused whichever tank items was strongest to be nerfed patch after patch for years. 

Whenever tank itemization has been good, **bruisers have built it and become better tanks**. Cinderhulk is the first item in a long time that has leveled the playing field, and it wouldn't be able to do so without ALL 3 of the following:

-%HP to give actual tank builds more than bruiser builds
-Sunfire passive to help tanks clear the jungle with similar speed to bruisers (who can actually build damage to clear faster AND gank better)
-Smite locked, for two reasons: any top laner who wants to abuse it must pay a very real price (1 summoner spell) to do so, and so that bruiser junglers can't go Warrior to snowball and use their gold advantage to get ahead on Cinderhulk as well-they have to choose one.

Without all of those things, Cinderhulk would either not be able to fulfill its purpose, or bruisers would be able to build it just as effectively, negating whatever gains were made.

> [{quoted}](name=mi ramfan,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=cHqBMLcF,comment-id=000400000001000000000000,timestamp=2015-04-27T15:49:34.371+0000)
>
> -Smite locked, for two reasons: any top laner who wants to abuse it must pay a very real price (1 summoner spell) to do so, and so that bruiser junglers can't go Warrior to snowball and use their gold advantage to get ahead on Cinderhulk as well-they have to choose one.


No, just no.   This is the part you junglers don't seem to understand.  Top lane isn't giving up ANYTHING, really.  Smite allows them to take a jungle camp and go to lane with an experience advantage, and then they rush buy the Skirmisher's Sabre, essentially guaranteeing they win every trade in their lane thereafter.  Smite allows them to get an early advantage, making their choice of Summoner Spells difficult to punish.  It allows them to do more damage, AS A TANK, because they reduce their opponent's damage by 20% and do bonus true damage to them in trades.  Finally, it allows them to build the only scaling tank item in the game.

Simply put, the only scaling tank item in the game should not be dependent on choosing the right Summoner Spell, and taking the jungle Summoner should not help you win your lane.

> -Smite locked, for two reasons: any top laner who wants to abuse it must pay a very real price (1 summoner spell) to do so, and so that bruiser junglers can't go Warrior to snowball and use their gold advantage to get ahead on Cinderhulk as well-they have to choose one.

It actually can't be Smite-locked, and for the very reason you see right now; the item is impossible to balance. The item needed to be powerful enough to rock the jungle, but that power doubles as pure DPS for any laner as well, and there's where the problem lies. Sure, laner AD Casters can build Warrior, but it will never stack up to the effectiveness of other Brutalizer items for laners, and that's because there's a separate laner build path for the stats desired. In fact, the Immolation effect is also available (though with better damage potential through jungle item solely). The only truly unique effect that's far overkill is the %HP effect, which SHOULD be available to any laner, Smite or not. Closing lane diversity is the entire issue.

"Metagolem" build has all but been removed since those old days, too. Mallet is absurdly clunky to build, Warmog's has been turned to fluff (partly because of limited tank stats... which OP is fighting for), Triforce can't slow, and Atma's was scrapped altogether. The fact we have no tank items available is not because it won't balance, it's because Riot dropped all the broken itemization resoundingly, and then decided not to compensate. What we're now getting is the effects of a starved item niche opening back up, which hardly means that Smite played any real part in it aside from being Riot's buildpath of choice.

My general point is: +%HP will not break laning in any way if it were a non-jungle item. It's still a lategame stat that is quite useful in multiple positions (not just jungle), but unlike the "Metagolem" Bruiser dependence, +%HP is exclusively usable by tanks, so it won't wear out from Bruiser usage. That's why it needs its own non-Smite buildpath. We should be working toward lane diversity, not away from it.

Another side-note: The DPS from Cinderhulk is meant to take the slow, drudging clear from tank junglers and give them near-Bruiser clear speed. However, if you take that clear speed and toss that same damage into lane, the effects are even greater because now tanks are hijacking the bruiser role. The real issue in the current meta is  that tanks are as irrelevant as ever in the jungle, and it takes a superpowered item to drag them back into contention. With overly powered monsters comes the price of needing longer consistency of DPS for clear speed, so if you add 50% to single-camp clear times while keeping the same travel distances as before, damage will be the name of the game moreso than ever. The free-DPS-effect from Machete & the upgrades works toward evening the field, but even that got nerfed to the point of uselessness by the time it hit live.

Cinderhulk is just a patch on a much bigger problem in the game, and it is throwing the balance completely out of whack. Tanks being relevant now doesn't cover that fact, and the price-raise in Cinderhulk is just the beginning of the balancing saga about to unfold, though it'll probably take all season to do, as usual.

They absolutely are not "giving up" a Summoner Spell to do it.  They are just choosing a different Summoner Spell.  Now, you might try to say, "But they are choosing a spell that won't help them in the lane."  That's not entirely true.  Smite allows them to take a camp and go to lane with an exp advantage, and then, once they build their Smite item, they can Smite their opponent to win trades or help close the gap.  Most top laner's will choose Skirmisher's Sabre, since that basically guarantees they win trades.

They aren't giving up anything.  They are simply choosing to win trades and have the only scaling health item in the game over something else.  And that's, honestly, bad design.  The jungle items were made for junglers to have more options, not to give top lane less diversity.

Top lane tanks are not the black sheep of League of Legends.  Sion became a strong pick without access to Cinderhulk; early Season 4 had plenty of top lane tanks in the meta.  And Cinderhulk, without the scaling health, is still a good jungle item; the scaling health doesn't even make a difference in their early clears because they don't have enough health to make an impact on the item.  Having a different tank item for tanks to build isn't a bad thing.  Warmog's isn't going to help a bruiser suddenly become a tank if he didn't build any other tanky items.

Simply put, the only scaling tank item in the game should not be dependent on having the right Summoner Spell.  That is bad design.

> [{quoted}](name=LeeDark,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=cHqBMLcF,comment-id=00040000000100000001,timestamp=2015-04-27T19:39:56.916+0000)
>
> They absolutely are not "giving up" a Summoner Spell to do it.  They are just choosing a different Summoner Spell.  Now, you might try to say, "But they are choosing a spell that won't help them in the lane."  That's not entirely true.  Smite allows them to take a camp and go to lane with an exp advantage, and then, once they build their Smite item, they can Smite their opponent to win trades or help close the gap.  Most top laner's will choose Skirmisher's Sabre, since that basically guarantees they win trades.
>
> They aren't giving up anything.  They are simply choosing to win trades and have the only scaling health item in the game over something else.  And that's, honestly, bad design.  The jungle items were made for junglers to have more options, not to give top lane less diversity.

Every top laner who's not taking Smite is taking Flash/Teleport. If they're taking jungle camps and then teleporting to lane, they're taking Smite/Teleport, so they're gank bait for any competent jungler throughout the laning phase. Or they lose all ins against Teleport/Ignite or Flash/Ignite top laners. Meanwhile, Smite gives you one free CS per wave? Please, pro players will hit the CS anyways and even most gold players will not need smite to help them last hit. 

Skirmisher's Sabre unenchanted is a waste of gold that gives no stats and costs 750 gold. With that 750 gold, the opposing Riven top is going back and buying two Long Swords to win every trade where you DON'T smite. Or the opposing Maokai is buying a Chain Vest and ignoring all your damage EXCEPT Skirmisher's Sabre procs. It's not an autowin item in top lane.

> Top lane tanks are not the black sheep of League of Legends.  Sion became a strong pick without access to Cinderhulk; early Season 4 had plenty of top lane tanks in the meta.  And Cinderhulk, without the scaling health, is still a good jungle item; the scaling health doesn't even make a difference in their early clears because they don't have enough health to make an impact on the item.  Having a different tank item for tanks to build isn't a bad thing.  Warmog's isn't going to help a bruiser suddenly become a tank if he didn't build any other tanky items.

You're right, top lane tanks are not the black sheep of the meta. Jungle tanks are, and there's a large number of tanks that are only really viable in the jungle. If Amumu, Nautilus, Rammus, Sejuani, Skarner, and Zac are not viable in the jungle, they aren't viable anywhere.

The HP scaling doesn't help tanks clear early game, it helps them scale into late game. The Sunfire passive is there to help tanks with their clear speed near the transition from early to mid game. Without it, bruisers can build damage to clear faster than the tanks, granting them more gold which they can use to build more damage to clear even faster and instagib laners, granting them more gold which...you get the point. With it, at least the tanks can clear nearly as fast as bruisers, making damage-focused jungle builds snowball much less. 

> Simply put, the only scaling tank item in the game should not be dependent on having the right Summoner Spell.  That is bad design.

I don't understand why. Making the only scaling tank item in the game dependent on having the right summoner spell is the only way to make it a tank item and not a bruiser item.

A waste of gold?? Challenging Smite has a 15 second cooldown and reduces the target's damage done by 20% for six seconds.  That has a potential 40% uptime.  So let's do some math.  That Riven you use as an example gets 3.1 AD scaling on her two non-ultimate damaging abilities.  Two Long Swords add, therefore, 62 damage to her combo if she hits you with all three jumps and the stun.  (This is a best case scenario, since she often uses one or two of the jumps just to help close the gap.)  Let's say it is level 4, since it doesn't take long to earn 750 gold.  Her abilities would do a total of 307 damage.  If she fits an attack in after each ability, she could do 825 damage, because her attack damage is 56 and grows by 12 by level 4, the Long Swords add 20, and her passive will add 25% to the total.  In total, the Long Swords add 160 damage to her full combo and four attacks.

Still with me?  Challenging Smite takes away a full 165 damage from that.  Challenging Smite REMOVES as much damage from her full rotation as the Long Swords added.  AND THEN we factor in the bonus true damage Challenging Smite does to her, which is 27 true damage on each hit, approximately  (depending on how fast you attack, since the damage is static over three seconds).  Therefore, Challenging Smite adds MORE damage to each of your autoattacks AS A TANK than two Long Swords adds to Riven's autoattack.  Remember, we have not even accounted for the returned damage from abilities, and Challenging Smite is already doing more than two Long Swords.  Riven's ability damage isn't all that impressive early on, even landing all three Broken Wings for damage, because she depends on fitting in autoattacks.  Top lane tanks don't have much trouble matching that ability damage early on, Sion, for example, can easily match 300 damage with abilities, and his 69 attack damage plus the 27 true damage on hit is more than enough to win the trade.  After all, his shield does damage and lasts longer, and hers does no damage and is gone quickly, since to get damage on all three Broken Wings, she surely had to dash in.

Do they risk either a lack of presence around the map by not taking teleport, or a lack of an escape in a gank if they don't take Flash?  Yes, but most of them give up Flash because winning your lane easily makes buying an extra ward or two no trouble at all.

Additionally, I fail to understand how requiring Smite prevents %bonus health from being bought by bruisers.  Bruisers do exist in the jungle.  They bought warrior because it was the most efficient item for them.  Jarvan still shows up in the jungle... but he buys Cinderhulk and still wants a couple of damage items.  He's still playing a bruiser.  It is easier for a bruiser to take Smite and then, because he has Smite, justify getting Cinderhulk than it is for them to justify spending gold on the much more expensive Warmog's.  Your argument that requiring Smite somehow magically makes it more tanky is ridiculous on its face, and doesn't even work out in practice.

EDIT: Oh yeah, forgot to add that in the above example, there is also a chance that while Riven is level 4, the Sion hit level 5 because he started with an advantage in experience, allowing him to do even more damage.

I'm surprised it took this long for this suggestion to be made. I feel like its been in the back of everyone's minds
I'd of made it and certainly thought of it. But the fact that warmogs had just recently gotten its HP nerfed from 1k, I figured there was no use bringing it up. I figured it was up to riot to decide whether to go back on their changes or not. 

I'm glad this is getting noticed, thought I was the only one.

I would give cinderhulk 10% CDR again or tenacity instead. 
It would just get the CDR on the back end when completing the item instead of using kindle gem.
Tenacity benefits fighters more than tanks, JS.

They should most certainly not move it to warmog's. People forget that top lane tanks were really strong in the meta before Cinderhulk, and this would give them access to that scaling without giving up flash or a combat summoner. What they should do is nerf Cinderhulk and the red smite so that the scaling is both less oppressive and only beneficial for junglers.
The problem with moving it to an anybody item is that it nerfs junglers, but buffs hecarim top, shyvana top, etc, which is the real problem.
Right now they're buffed AND they win basically every trade.  And they can rush it.  If they rush warmogs that won't be nearly as efficient for them as it is right now.
They being top laners or junglers?

I'd argue putting the bonus %HP on Warmogs would be better anyway. It doesn't make them stronger since they would have to invest a lot of gold into an item that only gives them health and health Regen. Right now Cinderhulk gives them %HP AND sustained damage which deals more than Sunfire cape. I don't see why you can't break it up since the %HP isn't what makes junglers great, but the sustained damage to make them more safer to jungle. 

Last time Riot used %HP it was on Spirit of the Ancient Golem and was deemed to strong then and removed. I'm not sure why they think anything would change when its put on a cheap item. Back when Warmongs was useful it was almost 2900 gold which is 700 more than Cinder and was 900 more than SotAG when it was out. I really don't see why people defend Cinderhulk as Tank junglers savior when the reason they are strong now has already been deemed OP and removed by RIot (just to add it back) and people are just using the smites for the added bonus on top of the cheap jungle item for free %HP boost. 

If Warmongs was to pick up the %HP boost it would be set for a late game item like %HP should be and where it actually starts being relevant. No top laner and nor jungler is going to build it first or even in their first 3, except {{champion:36}}. Its going to serve its same role and would be taken out of the early top lane. 

Overall regardless of what happens Cinderhulk needs to be nerfed or changed. Its too powerful especially with the smite buffs especially with champs in top sacrificing Flash and thats about the only champs we see being consistently productive in top.
Because junglers are prohibited from buying Warmog's if they are a tank?

Don't be sarcastic unless you think it through all the way. Tank junglers rush to finish their enchantment, because they're designed to help with clear. If the percent health is added onto warmogs, they get the bonus health later, making them weaker early.

Would they be weaker early though? Percent HP takes time to scale up, and if it's removed from Cinderhulk, the item would likely get improved flat HP. With no other items for health, flat HP would win out, so stronger early game. Mid game is where they may drop off for a bit, when waiting to get enough money for the new Warmogs power spike.

The major problem is that it turns Warmogs from a tanky item into a super ultra mega tanky item. Its synergy with itself is just too strong. You'd have to lower the health of Warmogs, or remove its other passive, and neither seems particularly appealing.
Both seem particularly appealing. By the time you buy warmogs the sustain it offers is worth far less than %hp would be.

Actually, I generally don't buy Warmog's on full tanks (Amumu, Sejuani, etc) but on supports who I've built full tank (Soraka with Warmog's is absolutely hilarious as a side note, thanks HP5) or on people who I need some additional tankiness and that scale well with health (Vladimir). In these cases, the Hp5 out of combat can be incredibly useful (Soraka because I can stand behind people after healing them up and get health back, Vlad because I have a ton of HP so it can help him get health back).
